metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python Classes and Objects
Python Classes/Objects
Python is an object oriented programming language.
content.html: Python is an object oriented programming language.

content.text: Almost everything in Python is an object, with its properties and methods.
content.html: Almost everything in Python is an object, with its properties and methods.

content.text: A Class is like an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects.
content.html: A Class is like an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects.

content.text: Create a Class
To create a class, use the keyword class :
content.html: To create a class, use the keyword class:

content.code_html:
class MyClass:
  x = 5

content.text: Create Object
Now we can use the class named MyClass to create objects:
content.html: Now we can use the class named MyClass to create objects:

content.code_html:
p1 = MyClass()
print(p1.x)

content.text: The __init__() Function
The examples above are classes and objects in their simplest form, and are not really useful in real life applications.
content.html: The examples above are classes and objects in their simplest form, and are not really useful in real life applications.

content.text: To understand the meaning of classes we have to understand the built-in __init__() function.
content.html: To understand the meaning of classes we have to understand the built-in __init__() function.

content.text: All classes have a function called __init__() , which is always executed when the class is being initiated.
content.html: All classes have a function called __init__(), which is always executed when the class is being initiated.

content.text: Use the __init__() function to assign values to object properties, or other operations that are necessary to do when the object is being created:
content.html: Use the __init__() function to assign values to object properties, or other operations that are necessary to do when the object is being created:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1.name)print(p1.age)

content.code:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):
self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John",
36)
print(p1.name)print(p1.age)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
 36)
 print(p1.name)print(p1.age)

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

p1 = Person("John", 36)

print(p1.name)
print(p1.age)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1.name)print(p1.age)

content.text: Note: The __init__() function is called automatically every time the class is being used to create a new object.
content.html: Note: The __init__() function is called automatically every time the class is being used to create a new object.

content.text: The __str__() Function
The __str__() function controls what should be returned when the class object is represented as a string.
content.html: The __str__() function controls what should be returned when the class object is represented as a string.

content.text: If the __str__() function is not set, the string representation of the object is returned:
content.html: If the __str__() function is not set, the string representation of the object is returned:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1)

content.code:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):
self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John",
36)
print(p1)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
 36)
 print(p1)

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

p1 = Person("John", 36)

print(p1)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = agep1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1)

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age 
  def __str__(self):    return f"{self.name}({self.age})"
  p1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1)

content.code:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):
self.name = name    self.age = age
def __str__(self):    return f"{self.name}({self.age})"
p1 = Person("John",
36)
print(p1)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age 
 def __str__(self):    return f"{self.name}({self.age})"
 p1 = Person("John", 
 36)
 print(p1)

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def __str__(self):
    return f"{self.name}({self.age})"

p1 = Person("John", 36)

print(p1)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age 
  def __str__(self):    return f"{self.name}({self.age})"
  p1 = Person("John", 
  36)
  print(p1)

content.text: Object Methods
Objects can also contain methods. Methods in objects are functions that belong to the object.
content.html: Objects can also contain methods. Methods in objects are functions that belong to the object.

content.text: Let us create a method in the Person class:
content.html: Let us create a method in the Person class:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age  def myfunc(self):    
  print("Hello my name is " + self.name)p1 = Person("John", 
  36)p1.myfunc()

content.code:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):
self.name = name    self.age = age  def myfunc(self):
print("Hello my name is " + self.name)p1 = Person("John",
36)p1.myfunc()

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age  def myfunc(self):    
 print("Hello my name is " + self.name)p1 = Person("John", 
 36)p1.myfunc()

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def myfunc(self):
    print("Hello my name is " + self.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)
p1.myfunc()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Person:  def __init__(self, name, age):    
  self.name = name    self.age = age  def myfunc(self):    
  print("Hello my name is " + self.name)p1 = Person("John", 
  36)p1.myfunc()

content.text: Note: The self parameter is a reference to the current instance of the class, and is used to access variables that belong to the class.
content.html: Note: The self parameter is a reference to the current instance of the class, and is used to access variables that belong to the class.

content.text: The self Parameter
The self parameter is a reference to the current instance of the class, and is used to access variables that belong to the class.
content.html: The self parameter is a reference to the current instance of the class, and is used to access variables that belong to the class.

content.text: It does not have to be named self , you can call it whatever you like, but it has to be the first parameter of any function in the class:
content.html: It does not have to be named self, you can call it whatever you like, but it has to be the first parameter of any function in the class:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(mysillyobject, name, age):    
  mysillyobject.name = name    mysillyobject.age = age  def myfunc(abc):    
  print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)p1 = Person("John", 
  36)p1.myfunc()

content.code:
class Person:  def __init__(mysillyobject, name, age):
mysillyobject.name = name    mysillyobject.age = age  def myfunc(abc):
print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)p1 = Person("John",
36)p1.myfunc()

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Person:  def __init__(mysillyobject, name, age):    
  mysillyobject.name = name    mysillyobject.age = age  def myfunc(abc):    
 print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)p1 = Person("John", 
 36)p1.myfunc()

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(mysillyobject, name, age):
    mysillyobject.name = name
    mysillyobject.age = age

  def myfunc(abc):
    print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)
p1.myfunc()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

  mysillyobject.name = name    mysillyobject.age = age  def myfunc(abc):    
  print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)p1 = Person("John", 
  36)p1.myfunc()

content.text: Modify Object Properties
You can modify properties on objects like this:
content.html: You can modify properties on objects like this:

content.code_html: p1.age = 40

content.text: Delete Object Properties
You can delete properties on objects by using the del keyword:
content.html: You can delete properties on objects by using the del keyword:

content.code_html: del p1.age

content.text: Delete Objects
You can delete objects by using the del keyword:
content.html: You can delete objects by using the del keyword:

content.code_html: del p1

content.text: The pass Statement
class definitions cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a class definition with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.
content.html: class definitions cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a class definition with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

content.code_html:
class Person:
  pass

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
When the class object is represented as a string, there is a function that controls what should be returned, which one?
content.html: When the class object is represented as a string, there is a function that controls what should be returned, which one?
